It is your job to coax a smile out  of them. A good line to remember is: "Santa thinks everybody should be  happy. Can you smile for Santa?" A  camera can only copy a child's smile --  it will take you to put it there.

WILLIE'S FACE. His expression reads: "Please kill me".

Wintry night. Ray Coniff's "Jolly Ole Saint Nicholas" sco views of the downtown blanketed in snow and decorated for the holiday. It is Christmas Eve, and the sidewalks thron with people rushing to do their last-minute shopping. A MOTHER and her two absurdly bundled CHILDREN emerge fro the crowd.
Hurry boys, we're gonna miss Santa!  She drags them across the street  toward the looming art-deco monolith  that is the big-city department store.
Mother and children crest the escalator to emerge on the floor.
There!

The older child is pointing at a prop gate with a candy-c letter sign: TO SANTA'S WORKSHOP. He runs and Mom shoos her younger child to join him. The boys cross the threshold of the gate and their eyes f with wonder. A winding path cuts through a flocked and candy-striped  forest, past a workshop filled with mannequin-elves busil cobbling Christmas toys, and finally arriving at... Santa, seated on his throne like a scarlet Messiah. The  younger child staggers forward to join the line of a hund other leaky-nosed worshippers awaiting an audience. At the head of the line the next waiting child is escorte to Santa's chair by a smiling tiny man (MARCUS) dressed a an elf.
An imitation BACK STREET BOYS quintet sings Christmas Car Grown-ups busy themselves draining their wallets as a VOI comes over the intercom:
Attention shoppers: the store will  be closing in five minutes. We hope  tomorrow is a pleasant Christmas and  thank you for shopping with us, your  friends.
Purposeful haste eddies the crowd.
The Photo Elf takes the digital photo and presents it to MOM.

(dutifully reciting  his spiel) My, what a darling picture! Are you  certain you only want the single?  Additional photos come in handy as  gifts for grandma and grandpa or a  wonderful remembrance for friends.
That's all right, I'll just take the  single.
He takes her credit card as CAMERA MOVES OVER TO SANTA. O his knee is a YOUNG BOY who whispers excitedly in his ear
(disinterested) Uh-huh... yeah... done.
Young Boy climbs off and runs away, A BRATTY KID jumps up Santa's lap.
I saw you in another mall.
(not even looking at  him) Right... Good for you.
You're not really Santa. If you were  Santa you could do magic.
(looks at him) You want magic?
Santa pushes him off his lap and shoves him on his way.
There, I just made you disappear.
Santa turns to his Elf,
...That it?
The Elf nods as he peels off a pointed prosthetic ear. Sa pulls a fifth of Old Grandad from the cushions of his thr

With the sound of closing circuits, banks of lights  systematically shut down in the various departments of th now empty store.
Downstairs the last of the store employees file out the d past an old SECURITY GUARD. Eventually Santa emerges.
Merry Christmas, Willie.
Up your ass.
The guard chuckles.
Have it your way, Willie.
Don't tell me which way to have it.

The Security Guard heads for a panel near the doorway and punches a key labeled ARM. An L.E.D. readout labeled "ARM counts down from 30 seconds. The guard exits the store, locks the door and heads home.
A large Teddy bear sits under a Christmas tree. Suddenly - it moves, bolting upright and sprinting from t room.
The alarm continues to count down -- 15... 14... The Teddy bear slides down the space between the railing the escalators. Landing on its feet, it barrels toward th door.
The Teddy bear scrambles for the door, crashing into  everything in its path.
Running past a clothing display, it rips the arm off a  mannequin without breaking stride.
It skids to a stop at the base of the alarm box, too shor to reach the controls.

It raises the mannequin arm, using the pointed finger on hand to press the "CANCEL" key on the keypad. Mission accomplished, the teddy bear rips off its head to reveal his true identity: Santa's Elf -- in civilian life known as MARCUS SKIDMORE. He is covered in sweat and pant like an asthmatic.

A hasp flips open and Marcus swings the door wide to reve a beer-guzzling Santa-in-the-off-season known as WILLIE T SOKE. He finishes the beer, crushes the can and drops it his feet next to eight more empties.
Ready.

Jesus.

Marcus reaches into jewelry cases and removes a few parti items. He drops them into a stock cart then checks a type list before moving on. Marcus pushes the cart through the store, gathering an od array of items that range from furs to gowns to shoes to  makeup.
Marcus arrives outside a doorway and looks in to see Will manning a large water drill and putting it to work on the store's vault.
How's it goin'?
I'm finished when I'm finished.
I'm goin' downstairs... (referring to list) I need a melon-bailer and a loofah.

Marcus moves closer as Willie pulls back the drill on the track. He places a screwdriver into the exposed lock asse and hits it with a sledgehammer. Suddenly, the door swings open and bundled cash spills to the floor. Both men are impressed.
Fuck the loofah, let's go.
Marcus and Willie wheel out two carts and roll them throu the open doors of a waiting van. As they slam the doors -

Willie settles on the rear bench as Marcus gets into the  passenger seat next to his Pillipina Mail-order wife of  several years, LOIS, who is dressed in expensively ugly  clothes, and whose mouth is ever down-turned in pruney  distaste.
Marcus, did you get the loofah?
Drive.
The van speeds away through the Christmas Eve night and  disappears into the distance, like the down of a thistle.
CAMERA ROCKETS INTO C.U. of An alarm clock ringing with a jolt.

Willie, in bed, blearily wakes to the insistent alarm. He tries to turn it off, but his fingers are still clotted w sleep. In a series of frustrated grunts and groans he becomes mo and more aggravated until, finally --
FUCK YOU, YOU FUCKING PIECE OF SHIT!
He bolts out of bed and throws the clock into the wall. He stoops for some beer bottle empties and hurls them at clock debris.
Fuck you! Fuck you! Fuck you!

One final scream and it's out of his system. He finds one last bottle in his hand, half-full with a cigarette butt  floating in it. He downs the beer and steps into the adjoining bathroom t brush his teeth.

Willie's walk brings him to a fancy eatery at lunchtime. he passes, he casually snatches a handful of car keys fro the parking valet key-box and moves on. As he rounds the corner into the lot he pushes on the var key fobs, identifying various cars when their alarms chir He seems dissatisfied until a brand new Cadillac chirps. Willie drives. He reaches over into the glove compartment and pulls out the registration. He focuses on the car own address.
Willie, eating a corn dog, saunters down an opulent hallw a beer swinging in one hand.

Willie, standing by the toilet, finishes buckling his bel and flips the flush lever. Nothing happens; no whoosh of rushing water. Willie, looking down into the toilet, gives the lever a c more clanking tries, and then grabs his beer and ambles o

The safe door swings open to reveal stacks of cash.
Willie scratches a lottery ticket. He's now wearing a Rol and some gaudy ring.

He reaches for another one and we see that on the bartop front of him are neat stacks of lottery tickets as yet  unscratched, and an untidy jumble of scratched ones. On the other side of the bar a MIDDLE-AGED STRIPPER vies his attention. Willie's ticket hits for $5.00.

He tucks it into the Stripper's G-string, swigs a drink, resumes scratching.
Willie and the Stripper stagger into his apartment, drunk As he passes his blinking answering machine:
I got messages. Go wash yourself.
I'm a dancer, I sweat.

As she exits, he activates the machine.
Mr. Soke, this is Andrew Kaplan again from the collection agency -- BOOP!
Willie skips to the next message.
Willie, I don't care man, I'm not  looking to blame anyone, but that  diamond isn't a real stone, man. I  took it to -- BOOP!

Uh, hello, this is Helen Axelrod --  you ran into my car last week? Well  I called State Farm but they have no  record of any insurance policy for  you and -- BOOP!

Willie, it's Marcus. It's that time  of year again. Pack your shit.  Phoenix.
To the chimey chords of "Sleigh Ride," we see Phoenix, Ar in MONTAGE / dressed for Christmas but sweltering under i oppressive winter heat.

Through the heat ripples rising off the pavement two mira like figures cross the infinite asphalt of the Saguaro Sq Mall parking lot -- Willie and Marcus in Santa and Elf  regalia, sweating and panting in the heat. Willie polishe off a pint of Smirnoff's and flips it towards a nearby tr can. It misses and breaks loudly on the pavement.
Jesus Christ! Can you maybe keep it  together for just ten minutes?!
He pulls some Tic Tacs out of his pocket.
For crying out loud, chew a few of  these... you drunken, fuckin'  imbecile!
Anchoring the huge mall complex is the large and upscale  Chamberlain's Department Store.
Amid the bustle of holiday shopping, an angry heavy-set m with a Grizzly Adams beard stomps away from the pursuing  store manager, Bob Chipeska.
Harrison, please I Just let me  explain. Financially, the --

You get what you pay for, Chipeska!  Five Christmases I've given my heart --  my soul -- my love to these kids,  and now what? Now you flip me for  some stranger who'll do it for peanuts  and happens to work with a real  midget! Lemme tell you something:  nobody cares! Nobody comes here for  the elf, Santa's the attraction! I  do Burl Ives songs; does this schmoe  even play guitar?
Harrison, it's not the money or the  midget. Believe me, if it was, I --  I don't think they like "midget". I  think you're supposed to call them --
Aw, forget it!
Harrison stomps away and right toward Marcus and Willie a they enter the store.
...Hacks!
Willie and Marcus stop in their tracks and watch the burl man storm out. Bob Chipeska watches with them.
Hi. Bob Chipeska. I, please, I, uh --  please don't listen to him. Great  resume and photo by the way.
Thanks... you know, we been at this  a long time an' all, so we like to  think we do a good job...
A Beautiful Girl wearing skin-tight pants walks by, catch Willie's eye. He stares wantonly at her ass, off in his o little world.
You two are the best men for the  job. Truly. So do not let his...  unpleasantness affect your performance  in any way.
Oh no, we're fine, w --
(irked, snapping out  of his daydream) Performance?
Willie's reaction worries Marcus.
Yea. Your performance... you know,  the...
Performance. Like sexual?
Excuse me?
Willie no, he --
You saying there's something wrong  with my gear?
Willie...
I'm sorry. Your gear?
You know... fuck stick.
OKAY! We're gonna head upstairs now.
Marcus shoves Willie, who stalks off. Marcus lingers to s things over. He forces a grin and shakes his head.
Such a card.
He's not gonna say "fuck stick" in  front of the children, is he?
No, no, no. Joke. Adult joke. For  us. Adults.
A long, long, long silence.
...Joke.
Another beat. Marcus pantomimes helpless laughter, noisel throwing his head back and holding his gut as it heaves w mirth. He is instantly composed.

On an upper floor of Chamberlain's the theme is "The Dese as Winter Wonderland." Cacti and tumbleweeds are wrapped  with lights and flocked with snow, and a team of nine stu burros are hitched to a sleigh. Rudolfo the Red Nosed Bur is tended by several Santa's elf mannequins. One in cowbo wear and another in a poncho and sombrero. Again there is a line of waiting children. Marcus makes h way through the line as kids gasp and cheer. He plays to crowd.

Yayyyyyy! Marcus gets to the head of the line, ducks unde the velvet rope and goes behind the flimsy cardboard set. Willie sits there morosely, head slumped, forearms on kne red velvet hanging limply from one hand.
What the fuck you doing, "fuck stick"  in front of the boss?

He takes a bottle from the floor by his feet and swigs of it. Marcus stares at him.
You don't like any guy. You think I  can't find another portly motherfuck  can run a water drill?
Willie just slumps there apologetically.
Don't tempt my hand. You blow this  and we're broke for the year. So  stop acting like you know something  because, pal of mine, you don't know  squat. You're gum on my shoe.
Yeah, yeah.
Now put on your fuckin' hat and get  out there.
He grabs the hat, slams it into Willie's chest and, as Wi rises, kicks him in the ass. Willie just takes it, shambl off.

Marcus leads a LARGE HEAVYSET BOY over to the throne. The boy eats a chocolate ice cream cone which is smeared all  over his mouth and T-shirt. Marcus lifts him with effort a groan onto Willie's lap.

It's okay. C'mon.

This penetrates the Kid's fear. He moves.

What do you want? C'mon, wuddya want?  A snot rag?

(to himself) ...Another fuckin' mongoloid. (shouts) Marcus I get him outta here before  he pisses on me.
Suddenly the Kid is moved to yank Willie's beard. He hold it stretched below Willie's chin.
(whispered to the kid) ...Let it go, you little bastard.
It's not real.
It was real. The hair fell out when  I got sick.
How'd you get sick?
I loved a woman who wasn't clean.
Mrs. Santa?
No, her sister. (whispers through  clenched teeth) Let the fucking thing go.
What's it like at the North Pole?
Like the suburbs.

Willie shoves the Kid:
Get the hell off my lap.

You are really Santa, right?

Okay.
The Kid backs away in awe, never breaking his reverent st As Marcus helps the next child onto Santa's lap Willie hi at him:

The Kid sits on a bench watching the entrance to  Chamberlain's. After a beat Willie and Marcus walk out in costume and cross toward the parking lot. The Kid follows from a safe distance.

Willie and Marcus walk across the huge empty parking lot, followed at a great distance by the Kid. They arrive at their cars -- Marcus' van and a beat-up ol Chrysler that is Willie's -- parked next to each other. As the Kid creeps closer, he is able to hear their  conversation. Just don't come in to work stinkin'  of booze again.
Don't worry about me. Get going,  you'll be late for your Wizard of Oz  Candy Bar Guild thing.

You tryin' to say something to me?

A large faux rustic bar filled to capacity with loosened- middle-management. Crammed at the far end of the bar, Willie stands out like sore thumb in this thirty-ish crowd. We follow his gaze all around the perimeter of the room u it connects with the drunken, glowering face of a HINDUST TROUBLEMAKER, sitting right across from him, startling Wi for a moment. Don't.

Why not.

Buy you one?

He shrugs:
It's my job, no big deal. I'm an  eating, drinking, shitting, fucking  Santa Claus.
Prove it.

Which?

Yes! Yes! Yes!

In the parking lot the barmaid finishes straightening her clothes and touching up her lipstick in the rearview mirr Willie, leaning against his car, still in his Santa suit, fires up a post-coital cigarette.
I got a thing for Santa Claus, I  don't know, I guess it's from early  childhood.
(taking a swig) Yeah, so's my thing for tits.

She gets out of the car.
I like you. Most of the people around  here are pretty uptight. My name is  Sue. Here's my number.
She hands him the slip of paper and ambles off, calling b over her shoulder:

-- the accompanying PAN OVER brings in the screaming  homophobe.

Willie pulls back a fist.
...'cause it's the last fuckin' thing  you're gonna see before I knock your  head off and sh --
WHACK-WHACK-WHACK-WHACK-WHACK! The man surprises Willie w a flurry of effective punches. In moments, Willie is on t losing end of homosexual panic.

Repairs. In the shop.

Willie escorts the Kid along a long walkway that leads to the front door of a large, opulent, new-money Southwester home. Willie admires the surroundings.
Nice digs. Daddy home?
He's on a adventure 'sploring  mountains. He been gone a long time.
Exploring mountains? When's he coming  back?
Next year.
What about Mommy?
She lives in God's house with Jesus  and Mary and the Ghost and the long- eared donkey and Joseph and the  talking walnut.
Who the fuck takes care of you then?
Granma.
(hatching an idea) Really... What's her name?
Granma.
As the Kid lets himself in Willie pulls out a black ski m and puts it on his head like a stocking cap.

He unrolls the mask to cover his face and takes out a  blackjack.
Willie enters the foyer as the Kid walks into the adjoini room. He approaches a figure in a La-Z-Boy watching TV.
Granma, Santa's here. Are you spry?
Grandma rises from her chair with the assistance of her w and begins to move toward Willie. She wears a bathrobe an thick glasses and has another pair of glasses on a chain  around her neck.

He watches as the senile old woman innocently putters awa He yanks off his mask and turns to the Kid.

The sound of a tumbler tripping and, suddenly, light swee in as the safe door opens to reveal a smiling Willie with his stethoscope in his ears. In the foreground a few stacks of cash and a folio.
